fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • David Veness, a former Metropolitan police assistant commissioner in charge of anti-terrorist operations, was named in a story as David Vaness and David Vanness (The right man, but the wrong call. Why Yates had to quit, 19 July, page 4). • Palladium – one of the platinum group metals – was wrongly described as radioactive (News International suspends websites after hackers target Sun, 19 July, page 4). • A report in some editions on stage 11 of cycling's Tour de France referred to Mark Cavendish as having won four stages in 2010. That should have been five (Cavendish takes revenge and green jersey with dramatic stage win, 14 July, page 1, Sport). • An article reporting on how British government officials approached nuclear companies to help play down the Fukushima nuclear accident quoted Tom Burke – a professor and former government environmental adviser – as saying of the Department of Energy and Climate Change: "I would be much more reassured if DECC had been worrying about how the government would cope with the $200m-$300m of liabilities from a catastrophic nuclear accident in Britain." The figures should have been $200bn-$300bn (UK bid to play down Japan crisis revealed, 1 July, page 9 turned from page 1).
